text:
Sam: The holiday season is fast approaching,
which means family gatherings, sweets galore,
and of course—gifts!

If you’re considering getting a smart speaker
for a science enthusiast in your life, Speaking

of Chemistry is here to help. 
We decided to pit a Google Home Mini and an

Amazon Echo Spot against each other to see
which one came out on top in a science-themed
quiz we wrote.

We also tried testing Apple’s intelligent
assistant, Siri, but that was less successful.
Matt: Hey Siri.

Siri: My web search turned something up for ”what's
the strongest material on Earth.”
Have a look.
Sam: Umm, I’d rather have you just tell me.

Matt: Although we don't think any smart speaker
is ready to work as a hands-free lab assistant

yet, we still wanted to find out which one
we thought could best answer the types of

questions that might pop into a chemist’s
head.

Sam: So, we each asked Alexa and Google over
30 science-related questions.
Matt: And maybe a few nonscientific questions.
Sam: Alexa

Alexa: I'm a bit sentimental, so I'm going
to say R2-D2.
You never forget your first crush.
Matt: Hey Google.
Google: This is a unicorn. *UNICORN SOUNDS*
Sam: But don’t worry, we did not include
those when we scored our very official quiz.
So how’d the smart speakers do?
Matt: Honestly, pretty well.

Before we give you our grades, though, let’s
look at how we scored them.
Zero was given for no answer or a wrong answer.
Alexa,
Alexa: Dimes can’t be converted into newtons.

Dimes measure amount of money, while newtons
measure force.
Sam: One was for a pretty unhelpful answer.
Hey Google.

Google: The 2018 Nobel Prize in Chemistry
winners are George Smith, Frances Arnold,
and others.

Sam: I guess Greg Winter didn’t make Google’s
cut.
Sorry, Greg!
Matt: Two was for a pretty helpful answer.
Google: 33 pascals is 0.248.

Matt: It kills me that you didn’t put units
on that.

Sam: Three was for an answer that was totally
correct.

Hey Alexa, what’s the chemical formula for
DMF?

Alexa: The formula of N,N-dimethylformamide,
also called DMF, is C-3-H-7-N-O.
Matt: So here are our final results.

For both of us, the Amazon Echo Spot’s Alexa
performed ever so slightly better.
I scored it at a 73% to Google’s 71%.
Sam: And I was a little less stingy, giving Google's
speaker 79% and Amazon’s an 80%.

Matt: Overall, we appreciated Google giving
us an extra significant figure in its conversions.

Alexa: Six feet is 1.83 meters
Google: Six feet equal 1.829 meters.

Sam: And it was also nice that it was more
forthcoming in sharing where it got its answers
from ... even if they weren’t super helpful.
Hey Google,

Google: On the website quora.com, they say:
It's the closest thing to the diamond-producing

bowels of the Earth, subjecting graphite to
intense pressure and heat.

Matt: Alexa, on the other hand, tended to
give more direct answers, which was great.
Alexa, What are diamonds made of?
Alexa: Diamond's material is carbon.

Sam: Another plus for Alexa is that third-party
developers, such as HelixAI, are already programming

skills to make Amazon’s speakers more helpful
for chemists.

Matt: So the official Speaking of Chemistry
recommendation is Alexa by a nose, but we
think either would be a solid gift for scientists.

Sam: Especially if they’re going to use
it for stuff aside from science trivia.

You know, shopping, listening to music, or
playing podcasts.

Sam: If you want to see the full quiz we gave
our smart speakers, along with some additional
comments from us, check out bit.ly/smartspeakersciencequiz.

Matt: And if you’ve got a smart speaker,
send us video of you asking your favorite
science questions.
Tag us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter.

Sam: And if you don’t have one, send us
some quiz questions on social media.

We’ll ask our favorites during a Facebook
Live after Thanksgiving.
Both: Thanks for watching.
Alexa: You’re welcome.
